title: Drug dealer accused of murdering Jodie Chesney names 17-year-old co-defendant as killer in court
text:
Jodie was with friends in Amy's Park, Harold Hill, on the evening of March 1 when she was stabbed in the back

A drug dealer accused of murdering girl scout Jodie Chesney dramatically named his 17-year-old co-defendant as the killer in court.

The defendant, who cannot be identified because of his age, is one of four youths on trial at the Old Bailey for the murder of student Jodie, 17, in east London.

Jodie was with friends in Amy's Park, Harold Hill, on the evening of March 1 when she was stabbed in the back by one of two figures who then ran off.

The court heard Jodie was not the intended target of a revenge attack over a drugs dispute.

Giving evidence, defendant Svenson Ong-a-Kwie, 19, denied that he was the attacker, telling jurors had he no 'beef' with any customers and was not seeking revenge for being stabbed in the leg on an earlier occasion.

'I did not kill Jodie Chesney,' Ong-a-Kwie said as he stood in the witness box wearing a blue shirt, with a grey tie and black trousers.

Asked who did stab Jodie, Ong-a-Kwie named a 17-year-old co-defendant.

His barrister Charlie Sherrard QC asked: 'Were you with him at the time?'

Giving evidence, defendant Svenson Ong-a-Kwie (left), 19, denied that he was the attacker. Ong-a-Kwie told jurors he regarded the alleged getaway driver Manuel Petrovic (right), 20, as a 'very close' friend who was like family

Ong-a-Kwie replied: 'I was, yes.'

Mr Sherrard said: 'Did you have any idea anything like that was going to happen?'

The defendant said: 'No.'

Ong-a-Kwie told jurors he regarded the alleged getaway driver Manuel Petrovic, 20, as a 'very close' friend who was like family.

He said they had been in business together dealing drugs and remained friends even after Petrovic crashed his car and lost Ong-a-Kwie's drug phone last December.

Ong-a-Kwie was pictured on CCTV in the hours before the killing, the trial has heard

In his evidence, Petrovic denied throwing Ong-a-Kwie 'under the bus' by distancing himself from him.

Last week, Petrovic told jurors the pair were more like business associates than friends.

Ong-a-Kwie, Petrovic and two youths aged 16 and 17, from east London, deny Jodie's murder.

The trial continues.
description: Svenson Ong-a-Kwie, 19, denied that he was the one who attacked Jodie Chesney (pictured) in east London. Asked who did stab Jodie, Ong-a-Kwie named a 17-year-old co-defendant.
